metadata.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar

facts.text: Respondent Anwar Ali Sarkar and 49 other persons charged with various offences committed in the course of their raid as an armed gang on Jessop Factory at Dum Dum on February 26, 1949.
Accused arrested some time after promulgation of West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, 1949 on August 17, 1949.
State Government by notification dated January 26, 1950 directed the case to be tried by Special Court presided by Shri S.N. Guha Roy.
West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, 1949 replaced by West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950 (Act X of 1950) effective March 15, 1950.
Formal complaint lodged before Special Judge on April 2, 1950.
Special Judge convicted accused on March 31, 1951, sentencing some to transportation for life and others to varying terms of imprisonment.
State applied for enhancement of sentence; High Court issued rule on May 1, 1951.
Anwar Ali applied to Calcutta High Court under Article 226 for writ of certiorari on May 1, 1951 to quash conviction and sentence.
Gajen Mali and others applied under Article 226 to quash pending trial before another Special Judge.
Full Bench of Calcutta High Court (Chief Justice and four Judges) on August 28, 1951 quashed conviction, held section 5(1) unconstitutional, directed trial according to law.
Cases related to armed raid on Jessop premises involving crimes of utmost brutality on large scale, incidents following raid, serious disturbances partaking of organised revolt.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 5(1) of West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950 is unconstitutional and void under Article 14 as denying equal protection of laws by vesting arbitrary power in State Government to direct trial by Special Court.
Whether the notification directing the case to Special Court is invalid.
Whether the special procedure under the Act derogates from essential requirements of fair trial.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 5(1) must be read in light of preamble and title for speedier trial of certain offences; State Government to refer only cases requiring speedier trial; not arbitrary.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Preamble of Act; construction principles from Halton v. Cove; Carroll v. Greenwich Ins. Co.

petitioner_arguments.text: Classification based on need for speedier trial is reasonable; wide latitude to legislature; presumption of honest exercise by executive.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; Chiranjit Lal v. Union of India; American cases like Engel v. O'Malley; New York ex rel. Lieberman v. Van De Carr

petitioner_arguments.text: Special procedure shortens trial but does not prejudice fair trial; differences minor.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 6-15 of Act compared to CrPC

petitioner_arguments.text: No discriminatory intent in notification; cases exceptional requiring speedier trial.

respondent_arguments.text: Section 5(1) vests absolute arbitrary power to refer any case, including individual cases, without classification; violates Article 14.
Special procedure less advantageous: no committal, no jury/assessors, restricted adjournments, no de novo trial on transfer, curtailed defence rights.
Speedier trial too vague for classification; allows anomalies like grave offence under Act, petty under CrPC.
Act delegates legislative power excessively without guidance.

court_reasoning.text: Section 5(1) construed to empower reference only for cases requiring speedier trial per preamble; discretion not arbitrary but for bona fide consideration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Literal construction imputes arbitrary power inconsistent with object and Article 14.

court_reasoning.text: Article 14 allows classification if reasonable and non-arbitrary; speedier trial basis valid; presumption of proper exercise by executive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere possibility of abuse does not invalidate; challenge administrative action if discriminatory.

court_reasoning.text: Notification justified by exceptional nature of cases involving brutality and organised revolt.
No reasonable classification; speedier trial vague; allows executive to pick cases arbitrarily, creating two procedures side by side.
Special procedure prejudices accused by short-circuiting CrPC safeguards.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deprives committal, jury, full defence rights.

holdings.text: Section 5(1) of West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950 unconstitutional to extent empowering State to direct any individual case to Special Court; violates Article 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chiranjit Lal Chowdhury v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Classification allowed if reasonable; State power to classify.

precedents_cited.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Overbroad laws void if capable of unconstitutional application.
Discriminatory administration of fair law violates equal protection.
Discretionary power to administrative body constitutional if not arbitrary.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers constitution of Special Courts and special procedure; s.5(1) held unconstitutional.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Article 14 equal protection violated; Art 226 for certiorari.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Normal procedure contrasted with special procedure; warrant/sessions trials.

outcome.summary: Appeals by State dismissed; High Court judgment upheld quashing conviction and holding section 5(1) unconstitutional under Article 14; trials to proceed under ordinary law.
outcome.relief_granted: Conviction and sentence quashed; trials directed according to law.

key_quotes.text: "A Special Court shall try such offences or classes of offences or cases or classes of cases, as the State Government may by general or special order in writing, direct."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Where a law purports to authorise the imposition of restrictions on a fundamental right in language wide enough to cover restrictions both within and without the limits of constitutionally permissible legislative action... it must be held to be wholly unconstitutional and void."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Romesh Thapar, distinguished by majority.

key_quotes.text: "Classification is justified if it is not palpably arbitrary."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for Article 14 from US precedents.

key_quotes.text: The necessity of a speedy trial is too vague and uncertain a criterion to form the basis of a valid and reasonable classification.
key_quotes.speaker: court
